awd_titl_txt: CPS: Synergy: Connected Testbeds for Connected Vehicles
awd_abstract_narration:
This research team envisions that connected testbeds, i.e., remotely accessible testbeds integrated over a network in closed loop, will provide an affordable, repeatable, scalable, and high-fidelity solution for early cyber-physical evaluation of connected automated vehicle (CAV) technologies. Engineering testbeds are critical for empirical validation of new concepts and transitioning new theory to practice. However, the high cost of establishing new testbeds or scaling the existing ones up hinders their wide utilization. This project aims to develop a scientific foundation to support this vision and demonstrate its utility for developing CAV technologies. This application is significant, because a synergistic combination of connected vehicles and automated driving technologies is poised to transform the sustainability of our transportation system; automated driving technologies can leverage the information available from vehicle-to-vehicle (V2V) connectivity in optimal ways to dramatically reduce fuel consumption and emissions. However, state-of-the-art simulation and experimental capabilities fall short of addressing the need for realistic, repeatable, scalable, and affordable means to evaluate new CAV concepts and technologies. The goal of this project is to enable a high-fidelity integration of geographically dispersed powertrain testbeds and use this novel experimental capability to develop and test powertrain-level strategies to increase sustainability benefits of CAVs.

To realize this vision, the first objective of this research is to develop a cyber-integration interface to increase coupling fidelity in connected testbeds. This objective will be pursued through a model-free predictor framework to compensate for network delays robustly. The second objective is to leverage this cyber-integration interface to create a connected testbed for CAVs. To this end, existing powertrain testbeds distributed across the University of Michigan campus and Environmental Protection Agency will be leveraged. The third objective is to use this connected testbed for (i) developing powertrain-level strategies to minimize fuel consumption and emissions in CAV platoons of mixed vehicle types, including light-, medium-, and heavy duty vehicles, (ii) uncovering the untapped potential of aggressively downsized powertrains, and (iii) understanding the limits of the benefits of connectivity due to various V2V communication issues. 

This research area provides a rich space to advance the science of cyber-physical systems and demonstrate their impact, as it spans multiple disciplines including time delay systems, system dynamics and control, hardware-in-the-loop simulation, engine control, powertrain management, and communication networks. The potential of CAVs to improve the sustainability of transportation is an outstanding example of how cyber-physical systems can have a societal impact. The connected testbeds concept, on the other hand, can benefit not only CAVs, but also a wide range of applications such as telerobotics, haptics, networked control systems, earthquake engineering, manufacturing, and aerospace. It can open new doors for researchers to perform unparalleled integrative collaborations by enabling them to leverage each other's testbeds remotely.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

inst.inst_name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor

por.por_cntn:
This project was based on the vision that connected testbeds, i.e., remotely accessible testbeds integrated over a network in closed loop, will provide an affordable, equitable, repeatable, scalable, and high-fidelity solution for early cyber-physical evaluation of connected automated vehicle (CAV) technologies. This project aimed to develop a scientific foundation to support this vision and demonstrate its utility for developing CAV technologies.


The following scientific contributions have been made: (1) A novel integration framework has been developed that increases fidelity of connected testbeds robustly despite the network delays. Comparisons on an example connected testbed against a well-established state-of-the-art delay compensation approach showed that the new framework not only achieved significantly higher fidelity, but also broke a fundamental limitation. (2) A connected testbed prototype has been developed, simulating a car following scenario with two CAVs with their physical powertrains in the loop. (3) A new CAV management algorithm at the powertrain-level has been developed to exploit the CAV technology to improve fuel economy and emissions. (4) The algorithm has been validated on the prototype testbed, demonstrating significant simultaneous improvement of fuel economy and emissions. (5) A new algorithm has been developed that leverages vehicle-to-vehicle communication to predict the speed of a lead vehicle accurately and robustly to improve economic adaptive cruise control performance. (6) A new framework has been developed that provides differential privacy in the vehicle-to-vehicle communication while maintaining the utility of the information for CAV management. (7) A new decision framework has been developed to analyze the long-term impact of fair machine learning algorithms and understand its potential application in vehicle-to-vehicle and vehicle-to-infrastructure systems. These scientific contributions have been documented in 24 publications.


The broader impacts of the project are as follows. The project provided training for 1 Post Doc, 5 PhD students, and 2 undergraduate students. 3 out of 5 PhD students were female. The PostDoc and one PhD student are now professors. 3 PhD students have full-time positions in the automotive industry, and 1 PhD student is an intern at Argonne National Laboratory, on target to graduate in Winter 2022. Both undergraduate students are pursuing graduate degrees. The PI has participated in the NextProf Future Faculty Workshop series, specifically targeting underrepresented minorities and women and helping them better prepare for a career in academia. The PI has supported the Research Education and Activities for Classroom Teachers (REACT) workshops that have provided 100+ K-12 STEM teachers free exposure to research. The PI has organized a workshop on CAVs that was held on April 28-30, 2019, in Ann Arbor, MI, and brought together the national and international experts in the field. Two more workshops organized at the Automotive Research Center, a U.S. Army Center of Excellence for Modeling and Simulation of Ground Vehicles, exposed to the project more than 100 participants from 10 institutions from government, academia, and industry. Additional dissemination has been made through numerous presentations to companies, two keynote speeches at international conferences, as well as a briefing to the Deputy Assistant Secretary for Transportation at the Department of Energy's Office of Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy. The PI has participated in the creation of a new graduate-level course on CAVs at the University of Michigan with modules based on the findings from this NSF project. The connected testbed prototype developed in this project has supported other research efforts with the U.S. Army Ground Vehicle Systems Center and Ford. The PI is currently serving in the NATO AVT-341 Technical Team on Assessment Methods and Tools for Mobility of Autonomous Military Ground Systems as a task lead, disseminating ideas originating from this project to NATO countries. The project has created new research infrastructure at the University of Michigan with the connected testbed prototype; a similar infrastructure is now being built at Clemson University.  The connected testbeds paradigm is expected to help with providing more equitable access to testbeds and achieving a more inclusive culture in research, education, and training. At the societal level, the project's results and activities on connected testbeds and CAVs will ultimately support the welfare of our society by accelerating the development of engineering solutions to worldwide challenges such as reducing our dependence on oil, reducing carbon emissions, improving transportation efficiency and safety, developing smart cities, and ultimately creating a more sustainable energy and transportation infrastructure.


 

 

 


Last Modified: 01/17/2022
Modified by: Tulga Ersal
